# IoT Network Collision Security Mitigation Plan

## Threat Overview  
IoT deployments rely on unique identifiers to distinguish devices; collisions occur when two or more devices share the same ID at any layer.

reviews.text: **Identifier collisions** (e.g. duplicate device IDs, client IDs or certificates) can cause session confusion or device takeovers.

reviews.text: For example, if two IoT sensors connect with the same MQTT client ID, one will repeatedly knock the other offline ([Conflicting MQTT client IDs - AWS IoT Device Defender](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/iot-device-defender/latest/devguide/audit-chk-conflicting-client-ids.html#:~:text=Why%20it%20matters)).

reviews.text: Such conflicts force constant reconnections, lost messages or even device lockout (a de-facto DoS)

reviews.reason_text: Mentions AWS resource, not requirement itself.

reviews.text: The AWS IoT Defender notes that duplicate client IDs often indicate credential compromise or a DDoS attempt ([Conflicting MQTT client IDs - AWS IoT Device Defender](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/iot-device-defender/latest/devguide/audit-chk-conflicting-client-ids.html#:~:text=Devices%20with%20conflicting%20IDs%20are,a%20device%20unable%20to%20connect)).

reviews.text: IoT standards bodies similarly warn that reusing identifiers causes “unpredictable behavior” – akin to having two devices with the same MAC on one LAN ([](https://lora-alliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/la_faq_security_0220_v1.2_0.pdf#:~:text=No.%20Please%20see%20question%20,attached%20to%20the%20same%20LAN)).
reviews.reason_text: Discusses standards body warnings but does not enforce behavior.

reviews.text: In practice, UID collisions can enable **impersonation** (an attacker mimics a legitimate device’s ID) or **data confusion** (sensor data routed to the wrong endpoint).

reviews.text: **Network/MAC-layer collisions** occur when two devices share a network address.

reviews.reason_text: Link to Q&A about handling duplicate MAC addresses.

reviews.text: Similarly, duplicate IP addresses can cause address conflicts and ARP storming, leading to network outages.

## Probabilistic Fix (128-bit UID)  
To virtually eliminate identifier collisions, this plan mandates using **128-bit universally unique IDs (UUIDs)** for all device identities.
reviews.reason_text: Mandates UUID use to eliminate collisions.

reviews.text: As standardized in RFC 4122, UUIDs are 128-bit values designed to be globally unique without a central authority ([](https://nostarch.com/download/EngineeringSecureDevices_Chapter6.pdf#:~:text=clear,Linux%20RNG%2C%20as%20shown%20in)).
reviews.reason_text: Describes standard UUID usage for device identities.

reviews.text: In practice the collision probability is astronomically small.
reviews.reason_text: States low collision probability with UUIDs.

reviews.text: For truly random (version-4) 128-bit UUIDs, the number needed for a 50% collision chance is on the order of 2.7×10^18 ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20the%20number%20of,27)).
reviews.reason_text: Calculates needed for 50% collision chance.

reviews.text: That equals generating one billion UUIDs per second for 86 years ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=For%20example%2C%20the%20number%20of,27)).
reviews.reason_text: Provides UUID generation statistics without enforcing behavior.

reviews.text: Even generating 10^15 UUIDs yields only a 10^-9 collision probability ([Universally unique identifier - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier#:~:text=%7B1%7D%7B1)).
reviews.reason_text: Discusses collision probability calculations but does not enforce behavior.

reviews.text: Thus, using 128-bit IDs makes accidental collisions effectively impossible in any realistic fleet size.
reviews.reason_text: Mandates UUID use for near-zero collisions.

reviews.text: (By comparison, a 48-bit MAC address space is only ~2.8×10^14 large – much smaller – and is already known to produce occasional duplicates.)
reviews.reason_text: Compares UUID size with MAC address issues.

reviews.text: Technically, each device’s identity record will use a UUID4 value as its primary key.
reviews.reason_text: Explains UUID4 structure without enforcing behavior.

reviews.text: Generation should be backed by a cryptographically-secure RNG to ensure full 128-bit entropy.
reviews.reason_text: Mandates use of cryptographically secure RNG for entropy.

reviews.text: This probabilistic fix **dramatically shrinks collision risk**: even under worst-case birthday estimates, an attacker or error would need to generate on the order of 2^64 IDs before seeing a collision ([random - UUID collisions - Software Engineering Stack Exchange](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/130261/uuid-collisions#:~:text=A%20suggestion%3A%20tread%20very%20carefully,of%20entropy%20in%20each%20key))
reviews.reason_text: Describes probabilistic fixes reducing collision risk to a low level.
